abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show unsatisfactory
            outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and only modest
            institutional development impacts. Despite unfavorable
            outcomes, the project flexibility demonstrated by the quick
            responsiveness to the financial crises, as well as the
            active stakeholder participation during preparation, and
            implementation, did however contribute to the success of the
            project's physical components. But lessons drawn from
            the project are outlined as follows. To avoid discrepancies
            between the status of project works, and actual
            disbursements, contractors' invoicing should be
            streamlined to avoid unnecessary payments delays. Regarding
            resettlement issues - where indeed the livelihoods of
            affected populations are at risk - nongovernmental
            organizations need to maintain strong community relations,
            through an active role during implementation, enhanced by
            strong funding capacity to ensure land acquisition, and
            relocation issues are rightfully implemented. While the
            centralized project management did effectively correct
            actions as needed, demonstrating an effective monitoring,
            and coordination approach, it was however ineffective in
            directing the required changes. It is suggested that a
            programmatic approach to lending, i.e., Adaptable Program
            Lending, in Indonesia's energy sector, is seemingly
            more suitable to support long-term policy objectives, and
            institution building, demonstrated by the unsuccessful
            project outcomes of this operation's traditional
            approach to investment lending. Finally, the State
            Electricity Corporation - with a large investment program -
            was certainly not the company suitable for the use of
            "rate of return on revalued assets" covenant, to
            measure financial performance.
